channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Facebook Blocks Account of Liao Yiwu, Exiled Chinese Writer
item.description: The writer, who lives in Germany, said the social network suspended his account after he posted a picture of an anti-government Chinese demonstrator streaking.
item.dc:creator: By IAN JOHNSON
item.media:credit: Colin Delfosse for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Chinese writer Liao Yiwu, in Brussels on March 22, 2013.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China-Japan Dispute Over Islands Spreads to Cyberspace
item.description: In a new effort to bolster its claim to disputed islands in the East China Sea, the Chinese government has introduced a website under their Chinese name, Diaoyu. Japan already has a website detailing its sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: By KIKI ZHAO
item.media:description: The disputed islands in the East China Sea are called the Diaoyu by China and the Senkaku by Japan. Conflicting claims over the islands have exacerbated tensions between the two countries.

item.title: The New Year Around the World
item.description: Celebrations, with light shows, fireworks and even a camel ride, ushered in 2015.

item.title: Dozens Are Killed in Stampede in Shanghai
item.description: At least 36 people died in the incident in the city’s famous Bund riverside area, where tens of thousands had gathered for New Year’s Eve celebrations.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Security personnel and police officers at a Shanghai hospital where people injured in a stampede were treated on New Year's Day.

item.title: North Korean Leader Seeks Meeting With South’s President
item.description: In a New Year’s speech, Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, proclaimed he was open to a “big shift” toward improved relations with South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing: Gambia: President Says Palace Attack Was Conducted by ‘Terrorist Groups’
item.description: President Yahya Jammeh returned to Gambia on Wednesday and accused dissidents backed by foreign powers of mounting an attack on the capital the day before.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Storm Impedes Effort to Tow Ferry and See if There Are More Victims
item.description: Stormy weather in the Adriatic Sea thwarted efforts on Wednesday to tow a damaged ferry to port in southern Italy.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: Hundreds of Migrants Rescued
item.description: The Italian Coast Guard rescued 970 migrants Wednesday after smugglers put their cargo ship on automatic pilot, heading straight for a crash into the Italian coast, and abandoned the command.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Ebola Still Spreading, W.H.O. Reports
item.description: The Ebola virus is still spreading in West Africa, especially in Sierra Leone, and the worldwide toll from the outbreak stood at 7,905 deaths among 20,206 known cases at year’s end, the World Health Organization said Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Afghanistan: Many Are Killed When Rocket Hits Wedding Party
item.description: At least 26 people were killed late Wednesday when their wedding party was struck by a rocket in Helmand Province, the Afghan police said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Whereabouts of U.S. Spy Released in Cuba Deal Are Unknown
item.description: The family of Rolando Sarraff Trujillo has yet to hear from him, and there is suspicion that he is being extensively debriefed before the authorities move him back into society.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES

item.title: Anti-Putin Protest Fizzles as Police Sweep Square
item.description: A crackdown showed that Russia’s “white ribbon” movement has withered three years after it roared to life hoping to oust Vladimir V. Putin from power.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: A rally in Moscow’s Manezh Square on Tuesday in support of the Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny.

item.title: Cuba Arrests Dissidents 2 Weeks After U.S. Accord
item.description: A performance artist arrested Tuesday along with several dissidents and journalists after she sought to set up an open mike in Havana was back in custody on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: North Korea’s Kim Jong-un Says He’s Open to Talks With South
item.description: The North Korean leader, in a New Year’s address, said high-level meetings with South Korea could resume, days after a proposal from Seoul to resume dialogue.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: 35 Killed, 43 Injured in Shanghai Stampede
item.description: The deaths and injuries occurred at Shanghai’s popular riverfront Bund area, China’s state-run Xinhua News Agency reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Security personnel and police officers at a Shanghai hospital where people injured in a stampede were treated on New Year's Day.

item.title: Mission Ends in Afghanistan, but Sacrifices Are Not Over for U.S. Soldiers
item.description: As United States combat operations formally ended, many military families said they sensed they had already been forgotten.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By DAVE PHILIPPS
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers at Fort Hood, the United States' largest Army base, at a flag ceremony Tuesday, the day before the end of the Afghanistan mission.

item.title: Ben Ammi Ben-Israel, Leader of Black Americans Who Migrated to Israel, Dies at 75
item.description: Mr. Ben-Israel, a former metal worker from Chicago, became known as a holy father to members of the African Hebrew Israelites of Jerusalem.
item.dc:creator: By KENNETH CHANG
item.media:description: Ben Ammi Ben-Israel is greeted during festivities marking the holiday of Shavuot in the Israeli town of Dimona in 2009.

item.title: Skirmishes Flare Along India-Pakistan Border
item.description: At least three soldiers were killed in the latest confrontation, an exchange of fire that heightened tensions.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Memo From Berlin: Euro and Immigration Promise Challenges for Merkel in 2015
item.description: Though she is still popular at home and respected abroad, might this be the year Chancellor Angela Merkel loses her touch?
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: The impact of Greece’s economic crisis on the euro and pressures associated with immigration tensions at home threaten disruption for Chancellor Angela Merkel.

item.title: With Schoolgirls Taken by Boko Haram Still Missing, U.S.-Nigeria Ties Falter
item.description: Distrust between the two countries has resurfaced as the search for nearly 300 kidnapped girls has lost momentum.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Rachel Daniel, sitting with her son, Bukar, held a picture of her daughter, Rose, who was among nearly 300 Nigerian teenage girls kidnapped in April by the militant group Boko Haram. While the United States joined the Nigerian military in efforts to rescue the girls, they have not been found and the relationship between the two countries has frayed.
